description: Dive into "Capture Hamburg: Iconic Views Await" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capture Hamburg: Iconic Views Await

places.generalDescription: The Elbphilharmonie Hamburg, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, is the city's tallest building and a landmark concert venue with stunning views of the harbor. Visitors can explore historical landmarks like the Hamburg Rathaus and St. Michael's Church, enjoy concerts at various musical venues including the Elbphilharmonie, and take tours of the harbor area.

sources.snippet: A post shared by Stefan Franke (@tidephoto_daily) on Mar 13, 2018 at 12:13am PDT. In January 2017, Hamburg celebrated the opening of one of the largest and most acoustically advanced concert halls in the world, the Elbphilharmonie. With its wave-like roof and sculptural glass facade by Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron, the concert hall is a striking landmark perched on top of one of Hamburg's largest warehouse buildings.
sources.shortName: 10 Most-Instagrammable Places in Hamburg to Point Your Lens

sources.snippet: Officially unveiled in 2017, the Elbphilharmonie is Hamburg’s tallest inhabited building at more than 100 metres. Despite its considerable size, this project by Herzog & de Meuron still has a light, ethereal quality, and its enigmatic profile has been compared to waves, the sails of a ship or a quartz crystal. On that shimmering facade are around 1,000 curved windows, and at the very top is the Plaza, an observation deck and sleek cafe both open to the public.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

sources.snippet: Although built in recent times, the Elbphilharmonie is fastly becoming one of the symbols of the city of Hamburg, with its modern architecture that creates a sharp but graceful contrast with the antiquity of the HafenCity buildings. The Elbphilharmonie is one of the most photogenic places in Hamburg, and you can’t absolutely miss it. Whether by day, by night, or at sunset during the famous “Blue Hour”, you have to pass by it!
sources.shortName: The 12 most photogenic spots in Hamburg you can't miss

sources.snippet: When it comes to modern architecture, it is hard to miss Hamburg’s tallest building – the Elbphilharmonie!. The futuristic concert hall, known as the “Elphi” to the locals, towers above the Elbe and the HafenCity. Composed of wave-shaped glass facade, the building is designed to resemble waves –  a perfect reflection of Hamburg’s maritime character and as a port city!
sources.shortName: Hamburg Photography Guide: Breathtaking Places To Visit In Hamburg

sources.snippet: Die Elbphilharmonie, ein 110 Meter hohes Konzerthaus, das an Segel, Wasserwellen und Eisberge erinnert, ist eines der Wahrzeichen der Hansestadt. Das liebevoll "Elphi" genannte Gebäude liegt am Rande der alten Speicherstadt. Es ist an drei Seiten von Wasser umgeben, was es noch imposanter und zum begehrten Fotospot macht.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

sources.snippet: What a surprise this 110-meters tall building made it on my list. Opened in early 2017, this now already iconic cultural sight is free to visit (even though you still have to get a 0€ ticket at the ticket counter interestingly). The building includes two concert halls, a hotel, a car park and an observation deck.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Instagram Spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: The Elbphilharmonie has only opened up in 2017 but is already one of the most iconic buildings in Hamburg. When you’re looking for pictures of Hamburg, the second biggest city of Germany) you’ll see the Elbphilharmonie on many of them. It’s one of the most Instagrammable buildings of the city.
sources.shortName: The 10 most Instagrammable spots of Hamburg

sources.snippet: A seriously cool concert hall in the HafenCity quarter, it’s famed for not only the spectacular architecture, but also its unique acoustics. View this post on Instagram. A post shared by Elbphilharmonie Hamburg (@elbphilharmonie) on Jan 11, 2019 at 8:00am PST
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hamburg

sources.snippet: Most people devotedly hate the still not quite completed Elbphilharmonie because the building costs literally exploded. An estimated 77 million € quickly decupled. With roughly 790 million € it will be Germany's most expensive cultural building.
sources.shortName: What to photograph in Hamburg

sources.snippet: Stunning warehouses in the warehouse district lead the way to Rödingsmarkt. The play of light on the roof of Hamburg most expensive real estate is a fantastic motive for eternity. Nearby find more photo opportunities at the Elbphilharmonie.
sources.shortName: Discover the 10 most photogenic spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: This is Hamburg’s tallest building and is a nice blend of old and new. This is an iconic building completely covered in glass. The design was modeled after waves and like the water, make the most beautiful reflections of its surroundings.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots in Hamburg Germany

sources.snippet:
Hamburg's newest and shiniest landmark is definitely worth a visit. Tickets for the concerts are hard to get, but the plaza is free to
 visit for everybody.
sources.shortName: Top 10 instagrammable spots in Hamburg

places.name: Elbphilharmonie Hamburg

reviews.text: Beautiful building, architecture and imaginative space.You can visit for free and just go up the two escalators and there you can walk outside the viewing platform. To get a ticket just go up to the kiosk and state how many, it's free.Youll see QR codes but don't scan them as you pay a small fee but they allow fast track,so unless you're short of time or the queue is really long you could do that but you'll all going in the same direction.Its open till late too and nice views at sunset.

I recently visited this striking building in Hamburg, and it truly exceeded my expectations. Architecturally, it is a masterpiece-modern, innovative, and with a sense of elegance that immediately stands out. The design is both cutting-edge and inviting, and the panoramic views it offers over the city and the harbor are absolutely breathtaking. It's one of those landmarks that feels both futuristic and seamlessly integrated into its surroundings, making it a must-see for anyone visiting Hamburg.

One of the aspects I really appreciated is the accessibility. Entrance is free, although you need to queue in order to receive a timed ticket to pass through the turnstiles. The process is well organized, and while there can be a wait, it is usually manageable. For those who prefer not to stand in line, there is the option to purchase a “skip-the-line” ticket for just a few euros, which I found to be very convenient and worth considering during peak hours.

Inside, the atmosphere continues to impress. The space is bright, airy, and beautifully maintained, offering plenty of opportunities to take in the surroundings at your own pace. The store located within the building is also worth a visit: it is stylish, well-curated, and features a nice selection of souvenirs and design objects that reflect the spirit of Hamburg.

Overall, this building is much more than just a viewpoint-it's a cultural and architectural highlight that combines innovation, beauty, and accessibility. I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to experience one of the most remarkable perspectives of Hamburg.

To go up to the top floor and enjoy the view from above, you'll need to get a ticket.
If you've already made it there and have some time to spare, you can wait in line and possibly get a free ticket.
But if you're short on time or don't want to wait, you can easily buy a ticket online for just 3 euros per person.
There isn't a café or bar waiting for you at the top - no coffee or beer - but the view is absolutely worth it.

places.address: Platz d. Deutschen Einheit 4, 20457 Hamburg, Germany

places.generalDescription: Miniatur Wunderland is a must-visit attraction in Hamburg, featuring the world's largest model train exhibit. The miniature recreations of famous global sites such as Hamburg, Austria, and Scandinavia are incredibly detailed, with animated elements like planes taking off and lights simulating sunset and sunrise. It's a popular tourist spot for visitors of all ages, offering guided tours through its intricate landscapes and bustling cities.

sources.snippet: A post shared by Mairi Beautyman (@i_scribe_design) on Nov 18, 2017 at 9:09am PST. On a beach you’ll never swim at, a lean man in Speedo-like swim trunks towels off his hair while his family looks on–just one tiny scene at Miniatur Wunderland. Located in Hamburg’s historic Speicherstadt district, this exhibit of a miniature world spread out over 1,350 square feet draws 1.3 million visitors a year, with the world’s largest model train display (50,000 feet) and an international journey that goes from America to Germany, Scandinavia, Austria and Italy.
sources.shortName: 10 Most-Instagrammable Places in Hamburg to Point Your Lens

sources.snippet: The Speicherstadt’s blockbuster attraction is a moving miniature world filling a whole warehouse. A bit like HafenCity itself, Minatur Wunderland is has been rolled out in phases since the early 2000s. It all began with a miniature railway rattling through 1:87 scale models of Austria, Central Germany and an amalgam known as Knuffingen.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

sources.snippet: Die Welt ist klein: Im Miniatur Wunderland kann man Sehenswürdigkeiten im durchschnittlichen Maßstab von 1:87 bestaunen. Das Miniatur Wunderland in der Hafencity beherbergt die weltgrößte Modelleisenbahnanlage der Welt. Sie ist mehr als 1,5 Quadratkilometer groß und hat über 16 Kilometer Gleisanlagen.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

sources.snippet: Kev and I are not museum people, but if we were to recommend one indoor attraction in Hamburg, Miniatur Wunderland ranks high on our list!. There are many reasons why we considered this model train museum one of the top things to do in Hamburg. First of all, it is the largest of its kind in the world.
sources.shortName: Hamburg Photography Guide: Breathtaking Places To Visit In Hamburg

sources.snippet: The world’s largest model railway exhibition is in Hamburg, and it’s adorably cute for photos. View this post on Instagram. A post shared by timurban (@timurban) on Mar 26, 2018 at 5:10am PDT
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hamburg

places.name: Miniatur Wunderland

reviews.text:
A great place for kids and adults! How much work and time has been put into this miniature world! You can easily spend the whole day there, watching the passing trains, taking off planes or many other interactive ideas.
What a pity that we had a very tight schedule and we could not stay there longer! We will have to come back again :)

Great place to visit if you have some spare time.

To be honest I think the ticket is a little too expensive. But it was a nice experience.

We went at 23:00 in the night and it was super full, that made us not enjoy it so much as we could not get close to the miniatures.

The store was nice and had good prices and the restaurant inside looked good.

A fantastic place for young and old, small or big. It is amazing to see how much efforts put in to simulate things in very details.
It is a must sight in hamburg.

Only small things, a better signage to guide people through for instance on the floor to make the flow of people more efficiently manage would be good. We made a short notice reservation and only limited time offers available. So it is recommend to book well in advance.

places.generalDescription: When visiting Hamburg, don't miss the Alter Elbtunnel, a historic tunnel that runs under the Elbe River. This early 20th-century marvel has been modernized and is now used for exhibitions. The tunnel connects St. Pauli-Landungsbrucken with Steinwerder peninsula in the port of Hamburg and is open to pedestrians, cyclists, and tourists free of charge.

sources.snippet: Von den St.-Pauli-Landungsbrücken führt ein vor über 100 Jahren eröffneter Tunnel auf die andere Elbseite. Einst nutzten ihn Hafen- und Werftarbeiter, um zur Arbeit zu gelangen. Verkehrspolitisch spielt der Alte Elbtunnel heute keine Rolle mehr.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

sources.snippet: This 426m long tunnel built in 1911 connects one side of the Elbe river with the opposite side. Though already over a hundred years old the tunnel still looks quite clean. It’s quite a view when walking down (or up) the stairs of the tunnel.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Instagram Spots in Hamburg

places.name: Alter Elbtunnel

reviews.text: Let me start with saying, this is FREE. It is really cool to see and be amazed by the engineering that went into constructing this. We walked down the stairs and took the elevator up. Make sure you stay out of the middle away from the bikes, they haul butt down there.

This is a public, toll-free tunnel for pedestrians and bikes. One tube is currently undergoing maintenance, so be aware of traffic in both directions when you cross.

The tunnel is manned, and if you don't feel like taking the stairs down, there's good elevators to take you down on both sides of the tunnel.

Built in 1911 and still very much alive beneath the Elbe.

The tiled tunnel feels more like a film set than public infrastructure, beautifully preserved and slightly eerie.

Walk it, bike it, or just descend for the atmosphere. If you have time, continue to Steinwerder on the south side for a quiet panoramic view of the city.

A perfectly kept tunnel running under the Elbe river. A fun free experience. I recommend taking the stairs down and the lift up.

The tiles are beautiful and adorned with various sea animals.

The tunnel connects central Hamburg with the docks and shipyards on the south side of the river Elbe. It is used daily by commuters as a shortcut across the river. Be sure to stick to the pavements inside the tunnel as cyclists move quite quickly.

places.address: Bei den St. Pauli-Landungsbrücken, 20359 Hamburg, Germany

places.generalDescription: St. Pauli Piers, also known as St. Pauli Landungsbrucken, is a historic and bustling landmark situated along the Elbe River in Hamburg, Germany. It serves as a significant transportation hub and entry point to the city, offering panoramic views of Hamburg's harbor, vibrant maritime activities, and picturesque waterfront promenades. Visitors can partake in boat tours, savor waterfront dining experiences, or simply soak in the lively atmosphere of this renowned location.

sources.snippet: Die Landungsbrücken von St. Pauli bilden eine Art Balkon mit Blick auf das geschäftige Treiben des Hamburger Hafens. Sie entstanden vor über 100 Jahren und bestehen aus schwimmenden Pontons. Mit diesen wird der Tidenhub ausgeglichen, der in Hamburg trotz 100 Kilometern Entfernung zur Nordsee immer noch bemerkbar ist.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

places.name: St. Pauli Piers

reviews.text:
This lively waterfront area is perfect for a scenic walk, with its mix of historic piers and modern ferries. The views of the Elbe River, bustling port activity, and the iconic sight of ships passing under the bridges are worth the visit.

Entry is free to the pier itself, and you could spend 1-2 hours wandering along the waterfront, stopping at the variety of cafes or hopping on a ferry for a harbour tour. Be sure to check the ferry times and landing bridges as each ferry offers different routes.

It's a shipping dock where different types of boat rides are available for the public. One can get a free ride on a particular boat with a Deutschland ticket. On the dock, there are many shops for souvenirs or fast food shops.

Boat Tours can be very expensive. The Ferry Lines are scenic enough to tour the Elbe, the ride is covered by the local transport ticket also by the Deutschland Ticket. Sit on the top deck when weather is nice and enjoy the views especially Elbstrand riding Line 62 which departs every 30 minutes.

places.address: Bei den St. Pauli-Landungsbrücken 8, 20359 Hamburg, Germany

places.generalDescription: The Hamburg Townhall, also known as the Hamburg Rathaus, is a magnificent neo-Renaissance building that serves as the seat of the city's government. Constructed in 1866, it features opulent state rooms and a vaulted hallway. Visitors can take guided tours to admire its beautiful decor and paintings. The building is adorned with 16 sandstone pillars and over 60 portraits of significant figures in Hamburg's history.

sources.snippet: The neo-renaissance style city hall was built in the 19th century is located right in the centre of Hamburg. The courtyard features a nice fountain and the whole building is illuminated at night. A good time to photograph it is the blue hour when natural and artificial light sources create a nicely balanced scenery.
sources.shortName: What to photograph in Hamburg

places.name: Hamburg Townhall

reviews.text:
I had a great time visiting Hamburg Townhall, even though I didn't go inside. The building itself is stunning, with its grand architecture and intricate details making it one of the most impressive landmarks in the city. Just standing outside and admiring the facade was an experience in itself.

The surrounding area is lively and offers plenty to explore. I walked around, took some photos, and enjoyed the vibrant atmosphere. The sunny weather made it even better, and I grabbed a coffee while sitting nearby, just taking in the view.

Even without an interior tour, the visit was well worth it. If you're in Hamburg, this is definitely a place to stop by, whether to admire the architecture, take pictures, or just enjoy the surroundings.

The former Hamburg city hall was destroyed by fire in 1842 and was rebuilt more than 40 years later at its current location. The current new city hall was completed in 1897.

The city hall is very beautiful.  Guided tours of the city hall are well worth taking, as you can enter areas not open to the general public and hear many interesting stories.

Currently, Hamburg's mayor's office, as well as the meeting rooms of the parliament and senate, are located in the city hall.

In one of the city hall's rooms, there is a large painting depicting the scene when the Speaker led a group of councillors into the new city hall after its completion. At that time, everyone wore neat formal attire. According to the tour guide, that formal attire was handed down through generations, was very heavy and difficult to clean, and is no longer in use.

The most beautiful room in the city hall is where the mayor meets with the administrative departments. In front of the doors of the room are two statues of goddesses representing justice and mercy respectively. On the door frame was written in German: GOTT MIT UNS., which means God is with us. Some abbreviations SPQH were seen outside the room. The tour guide explained that this was a reference to the Roman abbreviation SPQR. In Roman times, SPQR represented the Roman Senate and People. We think SPQH probably stands for Senate and People of Hamburg.

Absolutely do the guided tour. Frau Sabine Bendig led our group in English and it was amazing. Each room is so beautiful and meaningful right from the wallpapers to the busts and paintings. It's classy and rich without being gaudy.

places.generalDescription: Planten un Blomen, which means "Plants and Flowers" in Low German, is a captivating urban park spanning over 100 acres in Hamburg. It features themed gardens such as a rose garden, Mediterranean terraces, and one of Europe's largest Japanese landscaped gardens. Visitors can also explore a tropical greenhouse with otherworldly plants and enjoy free daily fountain shows set to music from jazz to Beethoven between April and September.

sources.snippet: If you had to make a list of Europe’s best urban parks, Planten un Blomen, 47 hectares of gardens, lawns, ponds, greenhouses and botanical plantations will be near the top. In the park’s green folds is the Old Botanical Garden, which was planted on the site of the city wall in 1821. Allow some time to poke around the five inter-connected greenhouses: The largest, the Schaugewächshaus has plants from Mediterranean climes and contains laurels, olive trees, palms and eucalyptus.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

sources.snippet: Auf Hochdeutsch bedeutet der Name Pflanzen und Blumen, und genau darum dreht sich alles hier: Planten un Blomen ist das Gebiet des ehemaligen botanischen Gartens, der historischen Wallanlagen und des Geländes der Internationalen Gartenbauausstellung von 1973. Die Gesamtanlage misst 47 Hektar. Zu den beliebtesten Bereichen gehören der Rosengarten mit 300 verschiedenen Arten, die Tropengewächshäuser und der Japanische Garten.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

sources.snippet: The famous public park in Hamburg, Planten un Blomen, is a leafy oasis in the heart of city centre. The urban park spans 47 hectares and includes a rose garden, an apothecary garden, a Japanese garden, a tropical greenhouse,  and fountains!. From the park, you can see the Heinrich-Hertz-Turm (Telecommunication Tower) standing tall at 280m high.
sources.shortName: Hamburg Photography Guide: Breathtaking Places To Visit In Hamburg

sources.snippet: This is a large park in an urban area that has a little bit of everything. You can expect to find a rose garden, Japanese garden, a tropical greenhouse, and an endless supply of fountains to photograph. You can also see the telecommunications tower or Heinrich-Hertz-Term from here which looks great in photos.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots in Hamburg Germany

sources.snippet: The big urban park of Planten un Blomen in Hamburg's inner city is open all year round and there is no entrance fee. A japanese garden, lakes and Hamburg's TV tower make for some interesting images. If you come here in the evening, you can get some shots of the daily water-light concert.
sources.shortName: What to photograph in Hamburg

sources.snippet: **Park Planten un Blomen is a large park in the middle of Hamburg. There are several area’s that make a nice Instagram picture. There’s a Japanese Garden, a Rose Garden and a tropical greenhouse complex.
sources.shortName: The 10 most Instagrammable spots of Hamburg

sources.snippet: The green heart of Hamburg is at this urban park in the city centre. There’s a botanical garden with a tropical greenhouse and the largest Japanese garden in Europe. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hamburg

places.name: Planten un Blomen

reviews.text: This is a must see if you are going to be in Hamburg! It's great for all ages. Put on your walking shoes and enjoy the sights and wonderful aromas of the flowers and herbs. So many plants to see. I would recommend bringing a lunch/snack and just hang out in one of the many places to sit, relax and enjoy this wonderful space.

A nice symphony of light and music in a beautiful garden/park. Be there at least one hour before the evening show, as it quickly gets crowded in the summer and vacation times. Bring some food and drinks and enjoy a 30 minute show for free.

What a beautiful park right in the city, very well cared for and tidy. Beautiful rose garden, Japanese and generally lovely planting and displays. Toilets are excellent and clean and they take contactless .

places.generalDescription: Treppenviertel Blankenese is a charming and historic landmark located in the Altona borough of Hamburg, Germany. This picturesque riverside area is known for its narrow alleys, elegant mansions, and beautiful parks connected by numerous stairs. The neighborhood's rich history includes influences from Prussian, Danish, and Austrian cultures. Visitors can explore the winding streets lined with stunning homes and tranquil gardens while learning about the area's past.

sources.snippet: Grab the S-Bahn or ferry to this quaint old neighbourhood ten kilometres from the city centre above the right bank of the Elbe. Treppenviertel literally means “Stairs Quarter” and that’s where this neighbourhood’s allure comes from. Untouched by the war, the Treppenviertel is a chaos of sharp, twisting alleys, walled by beautiful whitewashed houses and interlinked by stairways.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

places.name: Treppenviertel Blankenese

reviews.text: Worth the visit! It gives very Mediterranean feels. Down the stairs you'll find the lighthouse and the harbor with sail boats. What a sight!
Beautiful but very hard to walk ....a lot of stairs

If you make a trip to Hamburg you definitely have to see the Treppenviertel at Blankenese. But make sure that the weather is fine. It's easy to reach via S-Bahn. 5000 steps are waiting to be entered. The landscape itself is breathtaking. You can easily spend a whole day out there enjoying the sea and the nature.

places.generalDescription: Jenischpark, located along the River Elbe in Hamburg, offers a serene escape from the city with its historic mansion, scenic surroundings, and various attractions. Originally designed as an English garden, the park features rolling meadows, walking paths, and streams. Visitors can explore the Jenisch House and the Ernst Barlach Museum to admire sculptures and enjoy views of the river. The Flottbeckal Nature Reserve within the park preserves rare flora and fauna.

sources.snippet: Dieser weitläufige Park mit dem Jenisch Haus ist ein weiteres Highlight auf meiner Foto-Liste. Zu jeder Jahreszeit sieht es hier anders und immer verträumt aus – am meisten hat es mir aber der goldene Herbst angetan, der hier besonders spürbar ist. In so einem Park und in der Natur im Allgemeinen kann man perfekt ein Fotoshootings mit eurem Vierbeiner machen.
sources.shortName: 10 BESTE Locations für ein Fotoshooting in Hamburg & Umgebung | My favorite photo spots in Hamburg

places.name: Jenischpark

reviews.text: Place to go to relax. Nice view over Elbe river
Great walking by the water side. Trails with good views of ships, planes, birds, water. Spectacular place for Sylvester/new years eve with fireworks all around.

Beautiful and peaceful park in the westend of Hamburg with lots of open green spaces, magnificent variety of tall trees and plants. There is a little snack which serves delicious cheesecake and espresso. In the center of the park proudly sits the 19th century Jenisch House, where you can visit can on-going contemporary art exhibit.

places.generalDescription: St. Michael's Church, also known as Hauptkirche Sankt Michaelis, is a prominent Baroque Lutheran church in Hamburg. Its 132-meter-tall copper-covered spire makes it a standout landmark in the city. Visitors can ascend the tower, locally referred to as 'Michel,' using stairs or an elevator to enjoy panoramic views of the city and port, especially during extended evening openings.

sources.snippet: Northern Germany’s most famous Baroque church has seen a lot of drama in its time. The design is from the 17th century, and that 132-metre dark cupola at the top of the tower is visible from almost any part of the city. In 1750 it came tumbling down after a lightning strike, and was razed again by fire in 1906 to be totally reconstructed in 1912.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

sources.snippet: St. Michael’s Church is Hamburg’s most famous church and is one of the five main Lutheran churches. The building is iconic because of the 433-foot-tall clock tower that hovers over most of the background pictures of Hamburg from many directions. The clock tower of St. Michael’s Church was once used to navigate the ships on the river Elbe.
sources.shortName: Hamburg Instagram Spots: 13 Photo Spots in Hamburg + MAP

sources.snippet: St Michael’s Church is one of the most famous churches in Hamburg, and it is a really good place to go to get some 360 degree views of the city. You do need to pay to have access to the viewing platform, but it is only a small fee. Once you pay, you can climb the 400 steps or like us just opt for the lift.
sources.shortName: The most Instagrammable places in Hamburg

sources.snippet: This is a well-known church in the area and is characterized by its Baroque-style architecture. The copper roof and clock tower can be seen from miles and the inside is just as grand and beautiful. If you take the lift up to the top you can grab the perfect panoramic view of the city.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots in Hamburg Germany

sources.snippet: St Michael’s church is the most Instagrammable church of Hamburg. Build in 1912, St Michael’s church is located in the city center of Hamburg, next to the main road Ludwig-Erhard Straβe. The tower is a 132 meters high and can be seen from many points in the city.
sources.shortName: The 10 most Instagrammable spots of Hamburg

places.name: St. Michael's Church

reviews.text: Nice church, huge, very grand and spectacular. Our timing could have been better, they were having service on Easter so we didn't see much of the inside. But it looked like it was certainly worth experiencing both inside and out. Would have loved to have been able to go up the tower and see the crypt!

St. Michael's Church is a very beautiful and famous place in Hamburg. The building is big and impressive from outside, and inside it looks peaceful and bright. You can also go up to the tower and see a great view of the whole city. It is a nice place to visit for history, architecture, and quiet time.

I would highly recommend visiting St Michael's church as the view from the top of the tower is probably the best in the city!

To go up there is a small side building to buy your tickets and any souvenirs you may want, we only got the tower tickets at around €8 each. To get there you have to climb a few sets of stairs before reaching the main elevator to the top.

Once on top of the tower you'll have full 360 panoramic views of the city, just beware the bell does still ring up the top and it made my friends and I jump!

places.generalDescription: The Port of Hamburg, the largest container port in Germany and one of the world's biggest, is strategically located on the river Elbe. It serves as a crucial link between Eastern and Central Europe, offering safe docking for various vessels including containerships, oil tankers, and cruise ships. A visit to Hamburg would be incomplete without exploring this bustling harbor area or taking a boat tour to get an up-close view of its operations.

sources.snippet: Europe's second largest port extends from the cruise terminal to the historic Speicherstadt and the Landungsbrücken to the modern container port.
sources.shortName: Photo spots in the UNESCO World Heritage Site: Speicherstadt & Kontorhaus district

places.name: Port of Hamburg

reviews.text:
I took a boat tour of the Port of Hamburg and it was a fascinating experience. I saw giant cargo ships, observed the loading and unloading operations.
Overall, I highly recommend this tour for anyone interested in seeing the Port of Hamburg up close.

there was a festival at the day I arrived, so it was really crowded, full of people everywhere, but after that it was so peaceful there, the air was fresh and the water was clean, it was just so nice to sit there and enjoy the sunshine, both day and night views were so beautiful!! Hamburg is definitely one of my favorite places in Europe!

The port is just huge! We took a tour on a boat for 20€ in order to admire the majesty of the cranes and the huge ships parked on the deck being loaded by containers. There are so many things to see but you need a guide to get the full experience

places.generalDescription: Nestled just a stone's throw from Hamburg, the Boberger Dünenhaus offers an enchanting dune landscape reminiscent of coastal retreats. This hidden gem is particularly captivating during sunrise and sunset, making it a favorite spot for photography enthusiasts and nature lovers alike. The golden grasses glisten in the soft light, creating a serene contrast to the bustling city life nearby. As you wander through this unique area, you'll feel as if you've been transported to the North Sea—minus only the sound of crashing waves.

sources.snippet: Eine beeindruckende Dünenlandschaft wie am Meer – auch das findet man in unmittelbarer Nähe von Hamburg. Besonders zum Sonnenaufgang und Sonnenuntergang ist das einerseits eine meiner Lieblingslocations für Fotos, andererseits auch ein echter Insider-Tipp für Wanderungen in der Freizeit. Die Gräser schimmern golden im Licht, die endlose Weite ohne viele Menschen setzt einen Kontrast zur belebten Stadt.
sources.shortName: 10 BESTE Locations für ein Fotoshooting in Hamburg & Umgebung | My favorite photo spots in Hamburg

places.name: Boberger Dünenhaus

reviews.text: Just an amazing place to walk and explore with dunes and forest together, this is a nature exception environment. it has a lot of pathways and little secret spots to explore .. Im looking forward to go in the summer to try the lake and have a swimming day and picnic too.
Nice place and unique in Hamburg
Beautiful desert landscape, perfect for picnics, sand play for kids and a gorgeous backdrop for nature or portrait photography!

places.generalDescription: Located in Hamburg, the Deichtorhallen is a unique art museum housed in former market halls. The museum showcases contemporary art and photography, with one hall featuring large-scale exhibitions by renowned artists like Andy Warhol and Louise Bourgeois, while the other focuses on photographic displays and hosts the Triennial of Photography Hamburg every three years. The industrial steel and glass architecture provides a stunning backdrop for the diverse artworks on display.

sources.snippet: Between the Hauptbahnhof and Hafencity is an exhibition centre for art and photography in glass, brick and steel market halls erected in the 1910s. The Deichtorhallen are a sight to behold from the outside, in an Industrial style in the period between Jugendstil and post-First World War styles like Bauhaus and Art Deco. They also constitute one of the largest exhibition spaces in Europe that has put on landmark shows for Nobuyoshi Araki, Gilbert & George, Sarah Moon and Antony Gormley in the last few years alone.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Hamburg (Germany)

places.name: Deichtorhallen

reviews.text:
An impressive fusion of industrial architecture and contemporary art 👏🏼
The place oozes atmosphere - the vast, raw halls provide the perfect setting for powerful and large-scale exhibitions. During my summer visit, I experienced the Katharina Grosse exhibition, which was vibrant, physical, and emotionally intense. Everything comes together: the art, the architecture, the light, and the scale. An absolute must for anyone interested in art and architecture in Hamburg 👌🏼

2 great immersive art space near ZOB, with cosy cafe, bar, lockers and clean toilets. Loved the temporary home of photography based inside shipping containers while 2nd Deichtorhalle is under refurbishment. Just one thing: the book stores inside each space are definitely too small; limited range, expensive.

I was expecting a bit more from a modern art museum.
Current exhibition isn't really my kind of thing but it was nice to see some art that includes queer people and queer culture.

places.generalDescription: If you're seeking a break from the hustle and bustle of downtown Hamburg, consider exploring the charming Treppenviertel district. Its name, meaning 'district of the stairs,' reflects its winding streets and picturesque houses with a southern-European ambiance. This area is favored by Hamburg's affluent residents and offers stunning views from Sullberg over the river Elbe and the city.

sources.snippet: Das Blankeneser Treppenviertel ist mit seinen über 5.000 Stufen, pompösen Villen und niedlichen Fachwerkhäuschen immer wieder einen Besuch wert. Egal, wie oft man schon dort war, irgendwie landet man am Ende doch wieder am Fuß einer neuen, verwitterten Treppe und entdeckt einen neuen Garten, eine neue Bank mit perfektem Elbblick oder ein neues Haus, in dem man unbedingt wohnen will – wenn man mal groß ist. Da ist die Gefahr, sich zu verlaufen schon immens.
sources.shortName: 11 Instagram-Spots für die schönsten Hamburg-Fotos

places.name: Treppenviertel Blankenese

reviews.text: If you make a trip to Hamburg you definitely have to see the Treppenviertel at Blankenese. But make sure that the weather is fine. It's easy to reach via S-Bahn. 5000 steps are waiting to be entered. The landscape itself is breathtaking. You can easily spend a whole day out there enjoying the sea and the nature.
Beautiful but very hard to walk ....a lot of stairs

Nice place to have a walk from a wealthy neighborhood down to beach. There are some cafes and fancy hotels, restaurants around. Fresh air. No wonder it s the most expensive residential area in Hamburg

places.generalDescription: Elbstrand, located in Hamburg, is a popular beach along the River Elbe. It's a favorite spot for locals to enjoy sunny days with activities like grilling, playing in the sand, and jogging along the scenic trail. Adjacent beach bars offer everything from breakfast to evening drinks. Visitors can conveniently reach Elbstrand by taking a ferry without needing an additional public transportation ticket.

sources.snippet: The harbor ferry goes down the Elbe to the museum Övelgönne. Hamburg photo spot number one and the most beautiful beach and offer views of the largest container ships in the world, while in the West stylishly the sun goes down. A short break in the beach pearl and then by bike, bus or car back to the Jungfernstieg on the Alster.
sources.shortName: Discover the 10 most photogenic spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: Apparently the water quality is questionable, but I've been swimming there many times and survived. Nevertheless, it's definitely worth bringing your camera.
sources.shortName: Top 10 instagrammable spots in Hamburg

places.name: Elbstrand

reviews.text: I have wonderful experience being there early morning, taking sun bath listening sound of water, watching ships, cruises, And people coming for regular exercises

Elbstrand – A Slice of Beach in the City, unique and refreshing escape within Hamburg, where urban energy meets riverside calm. The beach offers lovely views of the Elbe River, passing ships, and even massive container vessels, giving it a truly one-of-a-kind charm. It's a great spot to relax, take a stroll, or enjoy a picnic with friends.

That said, it's not your typical soft-sand, swim-friendly beach.. the sand can be coarse, and swimming isn't recommended due to the strong currents and busy ship traffic. On sunny days, it can also get quite crowded, and there aren't many nearby facilities (like toilets or food vendors), so it's best to come prepared.

Still, for a beach day in the heart of Hamburg, Elbstrand offers a peaceful vibe, especially at sunset. Great for locals and curious visitors who want a different view of the city.
Beautiful and quiet artificial beach with a lot of people enjoying and with a view of harbor. It is around 2 km long, so you can easily find a quiet place to enjoy.

places.generalDescription: Hamburg's Alster is a popular destination, consisting of two artificial lakes - the Binnenalster and the larger Outer Alster. The Binnenalster offers shopping opportunities, while the Outer Alster is perfect for outdoor activities and sightseeing. This 160-hectare lake is a hub for water sports enthusiasts and provides a picturesque setting in the heart of the city.

sources.snippet: Die historischen Alsterdampfer, die vielen Gänse und Schwäne, das Grün am Ufer und natürlich das blaue Wasser mit den vorbei shippernden Segelbooten – die Innen- und Außenalster ist immer einen Besuch wert. Wusstet ihr, dass man sich sogar auf dem Wasser offiziell standesamtlich trauen lassen kann?. Mehr dazu zeige ich in diesem Blogbeitrag.
sources.shortName: 10 BESTE Locations für ein Fotoshooting in Hamburg & Umgebung | My favorite photo spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: The Alster is a river running through the city, creating two lakes right in the middle of the centre. Especially in spring and autumn, this area is worth a visit.
sources.shortName: Top 10 instagrammable spots in Hamburg

places.name: Alster

reviews.text:
nice and there are lots of shopping places nearby, europe passage is just around the corner.
Cafes and restaurants are worth to visit.
Fabulous views around. Beautiful lake and building mesmerizing your eyes..
Great place to come and chill on any day of a week.

places.generalDescription: Rickmer Rickmers is a 19th-century sailing ship that has been transformed into a heritage tourist attraction and art museum. It is located near Landungsbrucken in Hamburg, showcasing the city's seafaring legacy. The ship has a rich history dating back to 1896 and has traveled to various destinations around the world. Visitors can explore special exhibitions on maritime topics below deck, view old photos and nautical exhibits, and experience the restored crew and officer quarters.

sources.shortName: The 12 most photogenic spots in Hamburg you can't miss

places.name: Rickmer Rickmers

reviews.text: Nice historic ship with a museum and a restaurant. Has several floors and you can see two types of ancient ship engines in the engine room. Kids should love this place.

Great example of a tall ship with lots of personality and history. There's a small gift shop where you purchase a ticket for admission. Lots of nooks and crannies to explore. Very well done presentations. Restaurant for snacks and maybe a meal. Depending on your level of interest count on one to three hours here.
Amazing place. Loved everything about it

places.address: Bei den St. Pauli-Landungsbrücken 1a, 20459 Hamburg, Germany

places.generalDescription: Nestled along Hafenstrasse, Park Fiction is a beloved community space in Hamburg that offers stunning views of the Elbe River and the bustling harbour. This vibrant park is not just a picturesque spot to unwind with a drink; it also serves as a cultural hub, hosting film screenings and various events that bring locals together. The charm of Park Fiction truly shines during warm summer evenings when couples flock here to witness breathtaking sunsets behind the iconic harbour cranes and ships.

sources.snippet: A post shared by Carlo Bauz (@carlo_001._) on Apr 5, 2018 at 12:47am PDT. Sprouting from a harborside park in St. Pauli, Hamburg’s red light district, plastic palm trees reach for the sky. Park Fiction is an art project conceived as a symbol of resistance against development plans for the waterfront plot–which the initiative successfully changed after ten years of struggle.
sources.shortName: 10 Most-Instagrammable Places in Hamburg to Point Your Lens

sources.snippet: From this park you'll have a great view over the harbour at sunset. The metal palm trees (no idea why they are there) reflect in the sun and will look great on your pictures.
sources.shortName: Top 10 instagrammable spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: Plastic palm trees and a planted magic carpet will look amazing in your pics. View this post on Instagram. A post shared by Sven Te (@te_sve) on Jan 4, 2019 at 1:05pm PST
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hamburg

places.name: Park Fiction

reviews.text: A park where you can enjoy your beer with a harbor view with locals! Went there 3 times and never saw tourists! Skaters and lots of dogs!
Duty area, nothing to be seen except drink people not recommende to go their

Really cool park with a majestic view of the harbour, and basketball court and just cool vibes right in the heart of st Pauli. Everything is cool there but some people who hand around the park might spoil your experience, or not. Anyway the vibe and atmosphere and the place itself deserve 5 ⭐, sadly some people hanging around the area drag it down

places.generalDescription: Alster Lakes, located in the heart of Hamburg, is a favorite spot for locals and visitors alike. The sprawling lake is surrounded by verdant parks and historic mansions, making it popular among joggers and kayakers. It's a great place to start your day in Hamburg with a leisurely stroll around the 160-hectare man-made lake. You can grab a coffee from one of the many cafes or even try some unconventional breakfast options like ice cream from Luicella's.

sources.snippet: In my Hamburg Things to do post, I mention Alster Lake as a good spot for watching the sunset. I still say the same, so if you have time on your hands then definitely include this on your list. If you like photography then you know already that the colors right before and after the sunset bring out the best in every landscape and as a result, the photos turn out amazing.
sources.shortName: Hamburg Instagram Spots: 13 Photo Spots in Hamburg + MAP

sources.snippet: Our relexa hotel Bellevue offers on the roof top a magnificent view over the Alster lake - the white sailing boats, stunning patrician houses and small piers ensure you get that postcard picture. And if you still want to enjoy a glass of sparkling wine, we recommend to book our offer " Over the roofs of Hamburg” from 165.00 € for 4 days.
sources.shortName: Discover the 10 most photogenic spots in Hamburg

sources.snippet: The Alster Lakes—the Inner Alster (Binnenalster) and Outer Alster (Außenalster) are the heart of Hamburg city life. The two artificial lakes are popular recreational areas for both locals and travelers. It is common to see people sailing, paddle boating, kayaking, and rowing all around the Alster throughout the year!
sources.shortName: Hamburg Photography Guide: Breathtaking Places To Visit In Hamburg

sources.snippet: This is made of the inner and outer Alster lakes and is at the heart of the city. These were artificially created but still bring that nature and recreation to life in Hamburg. The Jungfernstieg is the best part of the waterfront to take photos.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots in Hamburg Germany

places.name: Alster Lakes

reviews.text: The Alster Lakes in Hamburg offer a escape within the city, perfect for outdoor activities, trail around lake is ideal for running and walking. For water activities, the lakes provide opportunities for kayaking and paddling, and rentals are available. In my experience, the Alster Lakes stand out as the best nature spot near Hamburg, offering a blend of scenic beauty and recreational options. I really liked it.

My go to running route during my 1 week stay in Hamburg. I personally find this is the best place to run in Hamburg as it is uninterrupted and the whole lake clockwise/anticlockwise is about 4km.

For runners, most part of the runs are on trails but they are use granites etc. Entire stretch of the lake are well maintained and three are many ducks and swans around. Would suggest going early morning as the whole place will be crowded late afternoon onwards.

The Alster Lakes area is absolutely dreamy. It's a great spot to watch the sail boats, the ducks, the people out for a stroll or a run. I sat on one of the benches for a bit and then walked into the city from there. What a treat for people living or visiting that area of the city. I enjoyed it so much that I booked a boat tour of both the Inner and Outer Lakes today.

places.generalDescription: Begin your day with a stunning view of one of Hamburg's most famous landmarks, the Landungsbrücken. This historic pier and floating island, built in 1839, was once the departure point for many emigrating to the New World. Today, it serves as a starting point for harbor sightseeing tours. The iconic 420-meter-long clock tower not only tells time but also features a water level indicator.

sources.snippet: The transport hub in Hamburg’s lively St. Pauli quarter where S-Bahn, U-Bahn, and ferries connect. It is also the entry point of the Alter Elbtunnel (Old Elbe Tunnel). Best Photo Spot: Stintfang or Stintfang Aussichtsplattform.
sources.shortName: Hamburg Photography Guide: Breathtaking Places To Visit In Hamburg

places.name: Landungsbrücken

reviews.text: This place  is one of the best outdoors in Hamburg. It's a beehive of activities and tourists movements on a warm weather day. You can take a free ship ride on the Elbe river, take coffee and enjoy the sea view. You can also shop for lovely Hamburg souvenirs and take awesome photos!
Useful station at the river edge with lots to do around it. This area of town is well worth a trip of visiting the area or want to explore the river edge

excels in its ability to paint a comprehensive picture. It's not just about the bustling ferries or the architectural grandeur; it's about the people who frequent the docks, the historical weight of the place, and the ever-changing light on the Elbe River. The slower pace allows for a deeper appreciation of the details-the salty air, the distant cry of a seagull, the intricate ironwork of the bridges.

places.generalDescription: Reeperbahn, located in the vibrant St. Pauli district of Hamburg, is a renowned stretch offering a unique blend of excitement and allure. Once known for its notorious reputation for crime and prostitution, it has transformed into a lively entertainment area with numerous bars, strip clubs, pubs, theaters, discos, and burlesque bars. During the day, it surprisingly becomes peaceful and welcoming.

sources.snippet: You probably want to be careful where exactly you point your camera when walking through the Reeperbahn, but you can find some really cool places to take some Instagram photos of Hamburg. For starters, there is the Beatles monument which is definitely Instagram worthy. You can join the many people on stag and hen do’s as they line up to get their picture snapped as they drape themselves over their favourite Beatle.
sources.shortName: The most Instagrammable places in Hamburg

sources.snippet: Als Hans Albers 1943 seine berühmte Hymne "Auf der Reeperbahn, nachts um halb eins" sang, gehörte die Amüsiermeile noch nicht zu den touristischen Hotspots von Hamburg. Das hat sich längst gewandelt. Die Reeperbahn ist hip, vom ehemaligen Rotlichtviertel ist wenig geblieben.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Sehenswürdigkeiten in Hamburg 2024, Karte und Geheimtipps

places.name: Reeperbahn

reviews.text: It's like the Red Lights District of Amsterdam but better. I would recommend going here when you know it's gonna be packed. Much more fun.
The red light area of Hamburg…plenty of places to have a drink and a bit to eat….a must see if your in Hamburg…lots of homeless people
A creepy and unsettling street. If I had gone alone, I would have been scared.

places.generalDescription: The Alte Harburger Elbbrücke, a 1,555-foot steel bridge completed in 1899, spans the Southern Elbe and is accessed through an imposing sandstone gate. It was the only route for road vehicles to reach Hamburg's city center for many years. Today, it offers a great experience for pedestrians and cyclists with its amazing views of the South Elbe. The bridge is a living monument and a unique feature in Hamburg.

sources.snippet: A post shared by Daniela (@danielapics.de) on Apr 2, 2018 at 10:55pm PDT. Composed of 1,555 feet of steel stretching over the Southern Elbe and accessed via an imposing sandstone gate, the Alte Harburger Elbbrucke was completed in 1899 in what is now the Port of Hamburg. For many years, traversing under its steel arches was the only way for road vehicles to reach Hamburg’s city center.
sources.shortName: 10 Most-Instagrammable Places in Hamburg to Point Your Lens

sources.snippet: A group of bridges that cross the river Elbe, the strong stone arches make for a cool Hamburg Instagram photo. View this post on Instagram. A post shared by Armin Ritter (@arminritter) on Aug 22, 2016 at 1:51am PDT
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hamburg

places.name: Alte Harburger Elbbrücke

reviews.text: Today was my second time in this bridge. The first time it was closed due to remodeling, today it was open and it is a great experience to cross it, one can do it by foot or bike and the view from the south Elbe is amazing. The steel construction is a living monument. Apparently is a one of a kind here in Hamburg. It was build at the end of the 1800' and it was the first auto bridge to connect to the north elbe to south Elbe. Very recommended!

This is a must visit bridge if you love cycling and want to discover places which you wouldn't be able to do with buses or trains. This bridge is opened only for cyclists and pedestrians which means you don't have to worry about any car passing by you and the two lane width of the bridge is more than sufficient for even a group passing by side by side on bicycles.

Beautiful bridge with a great view of the Süderelbe.
Nicely repurposed for bikes and pedestrians

Originally built in 1899 it has stood the test of time and was then the first roadbridge to cross the Süderelbe.

Be sure to grab a photo when crossing, in any kind of weather, it's beautiful.

places.generalDescription: Binnenalster is a picturesque artificial lake in Hamburg, fed by the River Alster and surrounded by stunning buildings housing shops, restaurants, and cafes. It's a popular spot for leisurely walks and boat tours. The area offers iconic scenery, especially during sunset when visitors can catch the beautiful blue hour. The serene beauty of Binnenalster makes it a unique and relaxing place to visit, with many people enjoying the view while resting or watching the fountain.

sources.snippet: Binnenalster - Settings: 20 shots stitched together 52mm 6.0sec f/7.1 ISO 160. Another iconic scenery can be found at the bank of the Binnenalster. Check out at what time the sun is gonna set and catch the blue hour.
sources.shortName: What to photograph in Hamburg

places.name: Binnenalster

reviews.text: The Binnenalster is an artificial lake fed by the River Alster. The lake is surrounded by magnificent buildings housing shops, restaurants, cafes and I think a few civic buildings too. The lake flows out towards Alsterarkaden and overall is a very picturesque place and good for a 20 minute walk all around the lake.
This is my most favourite place in Hamburg😊
Fountain in the middle of a lake. Walk around the lake and enjoy the views of the city and water.

places.generalDescription: Elbstrand is a charming sandy stretch along the River Elbe, offering a unique escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. While it may not be ideal for swimming, this 200-meter beach is perfect for building sandcastles or simply enjoying the serene atmosphere. Accessible via bus, metro, or an enjoyable ferry ride from Landungsbrücken to Ovelgonne followed by a scenic riverside walk, Elbstrand attracts families and couples seeking relaxation on weekends.

sources.snippet: Wie bin ich doch glücklich, dass es beides hier in der Stadt gibt. Im elegant-edlen Blankenese kann man nicht nur perfekt durch das Treppenviertel schlendern, das hanseatisch schicke Hamburggefühl auf sich wirken lassen, sondern auch schöne, natürliche und zeitlose Fotos machen.
sources.shortName: 10 BESTE Locations für ein Fotoshooting in Hamburg & Umgebung | My favorite photo spots in Hamburg

places.name: Elbstrand

reviews.text: HIGHLY RECOMMEND if you're in Hamburg on a sunny day. It's a unique beach in that it is located along the docks so you're not looking at an ocean view but at a major container port. The "beach" houses are beautiful as are the front yards leading down to the water. Also lots of restaurants and bars along the way from Elbstrand to Strandperle. One of the highlights of my Hamburg visit - but again, only do this if the weather is good.

Nice small beach. Near promenade. You can park on the street up the hill. Small bars near where you can take a drink. Beach is sandy and you can chill there...even nudists there...you can swim there...water was little bit cold about 7° so I did swim only for 15min...but it was 11th of april so in summer should be better🤣

The sand was too hot! I must complain ,I just wanted to visit to take a small stroll with my friend but I couldn't because the weather was too hot and the sand was boiling my feet . Acknowledging the fact that I was  wearing shoes I understand that I should have worn sandals without socks but I was never expecting it to be like this. The view from the beach was mainly cargo ships and boats but that couldn't ruin my day. The weather was a tough challenge I had to face but this won't change my great opinion on this place, I will definitely visit again once it cools down. The beach wasn't too crowded however the lack of shade was evident.
